projects.name: NoteLite

intake.problem: Existing note-taking apps (Notion, Evernote) are bloated and slow for users who just want fast, minimal block-based note-taking with real-time sync.
intake.solution: NoteLite - A fast, minimal block-based note-taking web app with Notion-like editing, Google sign-in, real-time Firestore sync, and mobile-responsive design.
intake.targetAudience: Users who want a lightweight, fast alternative to Notion for simple note-taking with block-based editing.
keyFeatures: Block-based content editing (6 block types, slash commands, markdown shortcuts)
Full keyboard navigation and ARIA accessibility

followup: User acceptance testing on production URL
notes: Auth reverse proxy implemented via Next.js rewrites (Option 3 from Firebase docs)
signInWithRedirect/signInWithPopup both broken by COOP policies - reverse proxy eliminates cross-origin access
Admin page created at /admin for debugging auth state and clearing stale Firestore data
Permissions errors likely due to userId mismatch between old test data and current authenticated user
OAuth config in progress: adding notelite.vercel.app to Google Cloud Console Authorized JavaScript origins

intake.problem: Personal budgeting app users struggle with line-item categorization when scanning receipts from multi-category purchases (e.g., Costco trip with groceries, household items, electronics). Business expense apps like Expensify and Dext support line-item extraction but cost $20-50/month and target corporate users. Consumer budgeting apps like YNAB, Copilot, and Monarch require manual entry or only capture receipt totals, making it impossible to accurately track spending by category from a single receipt. This forces users to either manually split transactions (time-consuming) or accept inaccurate category budgets, often leading them to abandon budgeting altogether.
intake.solution: Budget from your shopping list, not your receipts. Users build shopping lists in the app BEFORE they shop, tagging items with categories as they add them. At checkout, they photograph the receipt, and the system matches line items to pre-categorized shopping list entries using fuzzy matching. Unmatched items get flagged for one-tap categorization, building a personal item library over time.
intake.targetAudience: Budget-conscious consumers, young professionals (25-45), families tracking household spending at multi-category retailers (Costco, Target, Walmart). Currently use YNAB/Copilot/Monarch or spreadsheets. Weekly pain (every shopping trip). Proven willingness to pay $10-15/mo for budgeting apps.
keyFeatures: Shopping list builder with category tagging
Fuzzy matching (list items to receipt items)

intake.problem: Consumers have no effective way to organize and track warranties, receipts, and service documents across their household purchases. Critical purchase documents arrive scattered across multiple channels (email receipts, WhatsApp photos from family members, physical receipts, warranty PDFs) and never consolidate into one searchable place. This leads to missed warranty claims, lost money on expired extended warranties/service contracts, and inability to provide proof of purchase when needed for repairs or returns.
intake.solution: Warranty claim concierge service. Users upload receipts (AI-assisted), ClaimDone tracks warranties and sends expiry reminders. When product breaks, user submits claim via app. ClaimDone concierge team contacts manufacturer on user's behalf, handles entire claim process (forms, proof of purchase, follow-ups), and resolves claim. $10/mo subscription for unlimited claim filings. Competes on outcome (successful claims) not features (tracking).
intake.targetAudience: Homeowners and consumers (25-55) who make significant purchases with warranties - appliances, electronics, furniture, tools. Episodic but high-stakes pain (when repair needed, warranty expires unused). Currently use scattered workarounds (cloud photos, spreadsheets, email search) or DIY tracker apps (Warranty Keeper, SlipCrate). Proven willingness to pay (documented financial losses $100s-$1000s from missed claims).
keyFeatures: Concierge claim filing (we contact manufacturer, handle forms, follow-ups)

intake.problem: People are missing out on valuable local experiences (food popups, open mics, niche workshops, pop-up markets, community gatherings) because: 1) They discover them too late (via Instagram stories after events end), 2) Eventbrite focuses on mainstream/paid events not low-key local happenings, 3) No centralized proactive discovery tool for hyper-local hidden gems. Core pain: FOMO (finding out about great local events after they've happened), disconnection from local community, information scattered across Instagram/Facebook groups/local websites.
intake.solution: Radar-style map interface showing ONLY events happening in the next 4 hours within configurable radius (0.5-2 miles). No calendars, no planning—pure spontaneity. Push notifications fire at optimal decision moments (e.g., 'Taco popup starting in 30 mins, 0.3mi away'). Users subscribe to event types (food, music, art) and get real-time pings when interests activate nearby. Anti-calendar design—deliberately ephemeral. Events disappear from radar as they end, creating urgency. Novel approach: Radar metaphor for ephemeral local events (never been done), NOW-only view eliminates decision paralysis, visual pulse rings show real-time activity.
intake.targetAudience: Urban dwellers (20-40), socially curious, want to explore their neighborhood, interested in food/music/arts/culture. Currently rely on Instagram/word-of-mouth (broken experience). Weekly pain (every weekend, some weeknights). Proven willingness to pay .99/mo for lifestyle apps.
keyFeatures: Radar Map View (animated radar rings pulsing from user location)
Event Cards (name, venue, time, distance, photos)
Interest Filters (food, music, art, workshops, etc.)

intake.problem: iPhone users accumulate hundreds to thousands of screenshots over time, mixing temporary information captures (recipes, directions, app reviews, receipts, conversations) with their real photo library. This digital clutter makes it difficult to find actual photos, creates storage pressure, and causes organizational stress. Current workarounds are manual and time-consuming (search by date daily, mass delete periodically), and existing app solutions are new/unproven or inadequate.
intake.solution: Screenshots land in a processing queue outside Photos (inbox zero workflow). Users swipe right to keep to Photos, swipe left to delete, swipe up for actions (OCR extract, share, annotate). Forces triage decisions and prevents Photos pollution. No existing iOS apps use inbox workflow for screenshots.
intake.targetAudience: Productivity enthusiasts, ADHD users, knowledge workers (25-40) who take 15-30 screenshots/week and value inbox zero satisfaction
keyFeatures: Empty Inbox Goal (badge count, streak tracking)

intake.problem: Thoughtful people struggle to remember gift ideas they hear throughout the year, leading to last-minute panic shopping and generic gifts. When someone casually mentions "I wish I had X" or "Y is so annoying," those perfect gift ideas are lost. By the time birthdays/holidays arrive, people resort to panic buying whatever seems appropriate from Target, missing opportunities to give meaningful gifts that solve real problems or desires the recipient mentioned months ago.
intake.solution: Sift - Lock screen widget voice assistant for gift idea capture. Users tap the widget and speak for 15 seconds to capture gift ideas without unlocking their phone. AI transcribes and structures messy voice thoughts, extracting person names, items, and emotional context. Completely eliminates capture friction by placing gift logging at the point of highest visibility (lock screen seen 50-100x/day).
intake.targetAudience: Ages 25-45, thoughtful gift-givers, buy for 10-20 people annually, currently use Notes app/spreadsheets/mental recall (fails)

intake.problem: Young adults and socially anxious individuals struggle with initiating and maintaining conversations in everyday situations (networking events, dates, casual encounters). They freeze up, resort to generic questions, or avoid social situations entirely due to lack of conversation skills and fear of awkward silence. Current solutions are clinical tools for autism or therapy apps, not practical icebreaker coaches for everyday consumers.
intake.solution: Social failure journal that logs awkward moments, detects personal anxiety trigger patterns (time/place/topic), and generates personalized recovery prompts for next time user encounters that scenario. Gamifies social courage by rewarding attempts. Celebrates failure as learning data rather than preventing awkwardness.
intake.targetAudience: Gen Z and Millennials (18-35), socially anxious individuals, introverts, people re-entering social situations post-pandemic, young professionals attending networking events. Weekly to daily pain (every social situation). Proven willingness to pay -15/mo for self-improvement apps.
keyFeatures: Personal pattern detection engine (ML-powered trigger analysis)
Personalized recovery prompts based on YOUR failures
Gamified courage rewards (badges, streaks, confidence score)
Awkward moment archive (see past survived moments)

intake.problem: Teams need real-time messaging but Slack is bloated, expensive, and overkill for small teams
intake.solution: Lightweight Slack clone focused on core messaging: real-time messages, channels, DMs, simple UI. No file uploads, threads, reactions, search, integrations.
intake.targetAudience: Small dev teams (5-15 people), friend groups, small communities
